comments: This course introduces students to the nation's trillion-dollar tax-exempt sector with a focus on religious nonprofit organizations including congregations and other so-called faith-based institutions. Topics discussed during the semester include new and old questions surrounding church-state relations, the role of religion in American politics, empirical "faith factor" research, and attempts to estimate the social costs and benefits associated with diverse religious nonprofit organizations.  Most students enjoyed this course citing the professor as the main cause. Those that wrote negative reviews of the course commented on the large amount of group work. One student wrote, “There were too many task group presentations, which created a moral hazard.”   The majority of students wrote excellent reviews of Professor Diiulio. A student wrote that the professor was an, “excellent instructor who consistently conveys the material in a way that allows you to understand how to apply it in a manner in which you can be of service to others.” Students were excited to learn from Professor Diiulio.   This course is not listed as fulfilling any major college requirements. In addition, there are no prerequisites listed. The course is open to both freshmen and upperclassmen.
